posts.name: Raminder Singh
posts.cooked: Which notebook tools are most appropriate for writing down procedures, observations, conclusions and for drawing flowcharts?

posts.name: Raminder Singh
posts.cooked:
The HMS data management group has evaluated some of the tools currently available and created a comparison matrix.

datamanagement.hms.harvard.edu

Electronic Lab Notebooks

Electronic Lab Notebooks at HMS Lab notebooks are good for writing down procedures, observations, conclusions and for drawing flow charts and diagrams by hand. However, in order to accommodate the increase of digital data collected, researchers have...


or
docs.google.com

ELN Features Matrix

Sheet1 Yes No * Additional Information available on the ELN subpage Page last updated August 22,...

link_counts.title: Electronic Lab Notebooks | Harvard Biomedical Data Management

posts.name: Vanessasaurus
posts.cooked: Wow @raminder this is fantastic! Did you capture which of those solutions are open source, and how they are impemented? For example, if I wanted to bootstrap one with a Python backend, how would I find this information?

posts.name: Raminder Singh
posts.cooked: I am aware eLabFTW (https://www.elabftw.net/) is open source notebook developed using PHP/MySQL. On https://datamanagement.hms.harvard.edu/electronic-lab-notebooks, If you click on the individual tools on the left, it shows all the features and classification but somehow there is no good search/summary available.

link_counts.title: Electronic Lab Notebooks | Harvard Biomedical Data Management

posts.name: Vanessasaurus
posts.cooked: Have you thought about either rendering the Google Sheet (with Sheets API) into a static interface so it’s easier to browser, or creating a Github repository (with Github Pages) to render the information? It’s very hard to browse in the Google Sheet, and probably there is a lot of good information to share!
